content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. In a laboratory, a group of students constructs the circuit shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The circuit includes a power supply, two identical resistors, a capacitor, three switches, and an ammeter. Initially, all switches are open and the capacitor is uncharged. The students perform the following procedure.• At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, Switch <math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is closed.• At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, Switch <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is also closed. The students wait a long time for the circuit to reach steady state.• At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is opened and Switch <math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is closed simultaneously. <math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> remains closed.(a) On the following axes, sketch a graph of the current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> measured by the ammeter as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, from time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to a long time after <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Consider positive direction of current in the ammeter to be toward the top of the page.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. In a laboratory, a group of students constructs the circuit shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The circuit includes a power supply, two identical resistors, a capacitor, three switches, and an ammeter. Initially, all switches are open and the capacitor is uncharged. The students perform the following procedure.• At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, Switch <math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is closed.• At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, Switch <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is also closed. The students wait a long time for the circuit to reach steady state.• At time <math alttext="t equals t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is opened and Switch <math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is closed simultaneously. <math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> remains closed.(a) On the following axes, sketch a graph of the current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> measured by the ammeter as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, from time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to a long time after <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Consider positive direction of current in the ammeter to be toward the top of the page.

The students then construct the following circuit.(b) The circuit includes a variable power supply, four identical resistors, and an ammeter, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The power supply is set to various potential differences <math alttext="epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, and the ammeter measures current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>. The data plotted by the students are shown in the following graph.i. Draw a line that represents the best fit to the data points shown.
ii. Use the best-fit line to calculate the experimental value for the resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> of one of the resistors.

iii. The power supply is set to <math alttext="20 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math>. For a time interval of <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> seconds, calculate the energy dissipated by the resistor at the bottom left of the circuit in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

(c) The students add another identical resistor to the circuit, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The experiment is repeated, and the students plot their new data. Would the slope of the new graph be greater than, less than, or equal to the slope of the graph in part (b) ? ___ Greater than ___ Less than ___ Equal to Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
